Okay. Our next question is from Samuel Wilson of JPM Securities (sic) [JMP Securities]. Your line is open. You may ask your question.

John, I hate to do this as the last question, but I'd like to put you on the spot a little bit. A lot has changed in the last 90 days, and there's been a lot of press about your relationship with IBM and HP, and I wanted to end this call by you sort of going on the record and saying what you think the relationship right now is with IBM and HP, and how you think it's changing given all that's happened in the last 90 days.

Sure. So let me expand on the question, Sam, since you're going to be our last one on that because we want to end at 3 for our commitment to you all and keep the call as tight. If you look at our partner relationships, they continue to evolve very, very effectively, and we've done that over two decades here. And while some of the partners of the past will be partners of the future, when you're going into new areas, you're going to have different partners as you move into those. And so as you think about it, think about most of the demand we deliver through our partners is created by Cisco. And that can be easily moved to other areas. It's not all of it, but it's the vast majority.

The second element think about where our partnerships in the future will be and think of companies like Accenture and Wipro and MphasiS and Tata think of it as Intel and Microsoft, think of it as EMC and VMware and think of it as players like that in terms of where we're going. HP, clearly going to be a competitor and that happens, and when you have overlaps in terms of moving into market adjacencies, there are going to be some people you're going to partner with closer and there are going to be others that you are not. There will also be some areas like with IBM where we partner at times and compete at times and we do that at the Microsoft level.

But the key point I want to make is if you look at those 29 market adjacencies and just walk through them for a moment and think through how many different partner and partner sets we're going to need each one and think about how broad a range we're going into with a track record of being number one or number two and every time we've entered into a market, that's pretty unique. And there are going to be times when some of our partners say that's too close for me for you to do and I clearly understand that. There will be other times when I might feel the same in reverse. I actually think that's healthy.
Rob, I haven't got you in the call. A little about what is our relationship with our channels, how we fulfill business and then I will wrap it up, Blair if that's okay.
Okay.

Sure, John, and I think one of the most important things to consider is we did think through all of those implications relative to years ago. And we spent so much time on building what I think is the industry's most envied channel, that our ability to fill in those places where we drive demand primarily in the enterprise and service provider I think the capacity is out there as we speak. We will overlap with HP. We'll continue to work together with service partners, like IBM and Accenture and others. So I feel very comfortable with our routes to market, and I think we're in excellent place – in excellent shape to take advantage of the upturn when it occurs.

And so in summary, I said this, in my opinion, was the most innovative and operationally sound execution quarter we've had. And some of you might say, tell me that again and why. If you really watch it, our product introductory cycles, we're moving into new markets with a speed no one has ever even attempted to do, and I would argue with a speed probably five to ten times what anybody else has done.

Secondly, for the first time customers who've been watching this and they say, I get it, I now know what that innovation is in this business model. And secondly I watched it execute, you're going to make it happen. And that's the enterprise and service provider customers who are closest to us.

Third, our relationship with our customers and channels – never been tighter. And if you want the capability to be able to focus and pivot in one area and have Ned going with three or four major pillars in the consumer space, pivot again and go into the data center, and play in areas in terms of virtualization we haven't done, pivot again and go with a video architecture across the board, pivot again and be the world leader in collaboration and Web 2.0 and it isn't a Silicon Valley thing any more, a high tech company.

Our enterprise customers know we're the leader in this. They know that we've the thought leadership. They know we can help them more than anybody else, and our relationship has been tighter. And so while many of the things you do, "innovation-wise", it isn't till the customers say, "Hey, this is a benefit to me," and bring it home, does that occur. And you're really starting to see that occur.

So with all the appropriate caveats, which I thought we did a good job of covering in the script, Blair, I think what you look in terms of our future is a very bright future and my comfort level with the long-term both in terms of growth opportunities on issues we can control or influence is extremely strong.
So with that, Blair let me turn it over to you to close.

Great. Okay. So very quickly Cisco's next quarterly conference call which will reflect our fourth quarter fiscal 2009 results will be on Wednesday, August 5, 2009, at 1:30 PM Pacific Time, 4:30 PM Eastern Time, and downloadable Q3 financial statements again are available following this call including revenue segments by both product and geography, income statements, full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information, balance sheets and cash flow statements can be found on our website in the Investor Relations section. Just click on the financial section of the website to access the slides and the documents.

Again, I'd like to remind you that in light of regulation Fair Disclosure, Cisco plans to retain its longstanding policy to not comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure. Please call the Investor Relations department with any follow-up questions from this call. Thank you for your participation and continued support and this concludes our call.

Thank you for participating on today's conference call. If you would like to listen to the call in its entirety, you may call 866-357-4205. For participants dialing from outside the U.S., please dial 203-369-0122. Thank you.
